tool.name: CNVkit genemetrics
tool.description: Identify targeted genes with copy number gain or loss above or below a threshold, formerly called gainloss
tool.command: ln -s '$input_filename_file' ./sample.cnr && #if $segment ln -s '$segment' ./sample.cns && #end if cnvkit.py genemetrics ./sample.cnr --output gene_genemetrics.txt #if $segment --segment ./sample.cns #end if #if $threshold --threshold $threshold #end if #if $min_probes --min-probes $min_probes #end if $drop_low_coverage $male_reference #if str($Sample_sex.sex) == "yes": #if '$Sample_sex.sample_sex' == "Male" #set $sample_sex_val = "Male" --sample-sex '$segment_method_val' #else --sample-sex '$Sample_sex.sample_sex' #end if #end if $advanced_settings.mean $advanced_settings.median $advanced_settings.mode $advanced_settings.ttest $advanced_settings.stdev $advanced_settings.sem $advanced_settings.mad $advanced_settings.mse $advanced_settings.iqr $advanced_settings.bivar $advanced_settings.ci $advanced_settings.pi $advanced_settings.alpha $advanced_settings.bootstrap

param.name: input_filename_file
param.label: Processes sample coverage data file
param.help: cnr format and the output of CNVkit fix subcommand

param.label: segmentation calls
param.help: cns format and the output of segment

param.label: Min Number of covered probes
param.help: Minimum Number of covered probes to report a gain/loss

param.label: Assume inputs normalised to a male reference
param.help: females and males have +1 and -1 log-coverage of chrX respectivel

param.label: Drop very-low-coverage bins
param.help: Drop very low coverage to avoid false-positive deletions in poor-quality samples

data.name: gene_genemetrics
data.label: ${tool.name} on ${on_string}: Sample copy number ratios table

tool.help: Genemetics helps to identify targeted genes with copy number gain or loss above or below a threshold. This tool has one mandatory input and one optional input. The obligatory input file is the sample coverage with the format of “cnr” which is the output of CNVkit fix subcommand. The optional input file is segmentation calls with the format of “cns” which is output of the CNVkit segment subcommand. The content of this output varies depending on using one input file or two input files. The first four columns of output table show each targeted gene’s name and its genomic coordinates (based on the first and last bins with that label in the original target BED file, and thus the .cnr file).
